Material.Text:
H1: Language is said to be one of the factors that differentiates humans from animals, but new research shows that animals use language as well. In todays program, well discover how ethologists are able to teach chimpanzees and gorillas sign language, and how Rhesus monkeys emit different alarm calls to identify predators.
You may already know that songbirds alert each other with hundreds of different songs, but did you know that whales may know how to rhyme? Even elephants, giraffes and hippos, animals that were once considered to be virtually silent, communicate with sounds inaudible to the human ear. Join us on this fascinating journey!

Material.Text:
Dear Sir or Madam,

In reference to your advertisement in the Philadelphia Herald on February 24th, I would like to apply for the position of sales representative with your publishing company.
I am currently employed as a sales representative for an IT company. My main task is to develop and manage a client list, a role which I both enjoy and feel suited for. I am responsible for establishing contacts with potential new customers both at home and abroad, and I also conduct market research for new projects.
At the present time, I am looking for a company to fulfill the role of distributor in the Turkish market. As I already have experience working overseas, especially in the Middle East, I would welcome the opportunity to travel around the world for business.

QuestionText.Text: Who is the targeted audience of these expeditions?

Material.Text:
Mount Rainier Expeditions: Five-Day Summit Climb
JulySeptember
Cost: $1500

The Five-Day Summit Climb is the perfect opportunity for beginner-level climbers to reach Mt. Rainier's summit at 14,411 feet (4,392 meters). The first two days of the expedition focus on team building, familiarizing ourselves with the equipment, and learning mountaineering skills. On day three, we ascend up to Camp Muir at 10,060 feet (3,066 meters) and spend two nights there to acclimate to the elevation and practice more mountaineering techniques. We leave early on the last day to attempt the summit and return to the foot of the mountain. Completing this climb will give you the skills to attempt more technical climbs as well as provide you with breathtaking views of one of North America's most stunning mountains.

QuestionText.Text: Why is this vehicle a revolution in the automotive industry?

Material.Text: Introducing the SolaireCar, the world's first fully solar-powered automobile! The SolaireCar marks a revolution in automotive and green technologies, being the first car that is completely cut off from the gas pump and can charge itself. Gone are the days of toxic exhaust and costly batteries; here comes a new generation of vehicles that runs clean from an energy source that will never run out. The SolaireCar isn't just an environmentalist's dream; it's also a high-performing, durable, and roomy car. It seats five passengers, has all-wheel drive, and clocks speeds up to 120 mph (193 km/h), making it suitable for freeway and city driving. The revolution to clean driving has begun, and the SolaireCar is leading the charge. There's no limit to how far it can go!

QuestionText.Text: Why are Lincoln's political defeats surprising?

AnswerSentence.Text: Lincoln did not let his difficulties stop him.
Lincoln worked hard to stop slavery.
Lincoln ran for office many times.
Lincoln was the best president of the United States.

QuestionText.Text: Which of these statements summarizes the main point of this text?

Material.Text: Many people would consider Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) one of the best presidents of the United States. While most people know that he was president during the American Civil War and that he played a major role in ending slavery, what many people do not know is that Lincoln had many political defeats. In fact, before being elected president, Lincoln held only two political offices for a short time: one as an Illinois state legislator and the other as a congressman. In total, Lincoln ran for office ten times but was elected only three times. As a young man, he also had a business that failed, and he experienced depression. It is a testimony to Lincoln's strength of character that in light of so many drawbacks, his legacy is one of strength, integrity, and success.

To compliment the way he was treated by an employee.

QuestionText.Text: What is Mr. Johnson's purpose in writing this email?

Material.Text:
To: Athlete's Paradise Headquarters
Re: Shameful Customer Service

I wanted to draw your attention to the service offered in your Newberg branch. After twenty minutes of searching for help to find fitness equipment, I was finally able to corner a sales representative. She acted annoyed and as if I was a bother to her. She then did not know the answers to any of the questions I had, and when I suggested that maybe another salesperson or sales manager might be able to assist, she left me in the aisle and resumed chatting with her coworker at the cash register. I could also hear them laughing at me. Obviously, I did not buy anything that day, and I refuse to set foot in an Athlete's Paradise again because of this unacceptable lack of service and respect.

Sincerely,

Bob Johnson

To discuss habits that increase the risk for a stroke.

Patients who are recovering from a stroke.

QuestionText.Text: Apart from people at risk, who else is the targeted audience of Stroke Awareness Stations?

Material.Text: To better prevent strokes in our region, Valley Medical Center is proud to announce its Stroke Awareness Stations, which provide free, personalized risk assessment and education about the signs and symptoms of stroke. A stroke occurs when the brain's blood supply is blocked or when a blood vessel in the brain ruptures. Fortunately, certain procedures and treatments can reduce the long-term effects of stroke, and the sooner a stroke is treated, the better the outcome for the patient. If you or someone you know has high blood pressure, diabetes, high cholesterol, heart disease, or is obese, they are at risk for a stroke. Learn about what you can do to reduce your risk or help someone who may be having a stroke. Visit us online at www.vmed.org to find your nearest Stroke Awareness Station.

QuestionText.Text: According to the text, what is still unknown about the products used on organic foods?

AnswerSentence.Text: Made.
Replaced.
Expected.

QuestionText.Text: What does the term "derived" mean?

Material.Text: When most people hear the term "organic," they immediately assume that the produce referred to is healthier, more ecologically responsible, and pesticide free. While there's no doubt that organic farming techniques have helped advance nonchemical methods of controlling pests, it is in fact misleading to think that organic produce is free of pesticides. Organic farming only requires that pesticides be <u>derived</u> from natural sources and not synthetically fabricated. It does not exclude the use of pesticides altogether, and the pesticides used may be just as carcinogenic (cancer-causing) as synthetic pesticides. Unless you know the grower of your produce personally, it can be difficult to know which chemicals may be used on your food. It's food for thought, especially given the typically higher price tag of organic foods.

AnswerSentence.Text: It is helpful but not sufficient to reduce waste.
It hasn't been implemented properly in cities.
It isn't as important as decreasing consumption.
It has encouraged people to reduce and reuse.

QuestionText.Text: What is the author's opinion about recycling?

AnswerSentence.Text: To suggest ways to avoid buying too much.
To suggest ways to stop overeating.
To suggest ways to reuse food packaging.
To suggest ways to save energy when cooking.

QuestionText.Text: Why does the author mention meal plans?

AnswerSentence.Text: Using an old pair of jeans to make a purse.
Installing a shower that saves on water.
Buying a set of used dishes instead of new ones.
Donating lightly used items to charity.

QuestionText.Text: What might be a good example of repurposing?

Material.Text: "Reduce, reuse, recycle" is a mantra we have been hearing for some time now. Significant effort has been put into many citywide recycling efforts, but what about the other Rs in the slogan? Recycling is laudable, but how can we reduce our waste and reuse more things? One consideration to make in order to reduce more is to decrease our overall consumption. Creating meal plans for the week, looking for products with less packaging, and using energy-efficient light bulbs are just a few ways to minimize overall consumption and therefore waste. And as for reusing, people should consider donating or reselling usable clothing or objects and buying items secondhand. "Repurposing" is also becoming increasingly popular, taking things that would normally become trash and transforming them into something brand new.

QuestionText.Text: What is this text mainly about?

AnswerSentence.Text: It can be difficult to operate.
It is expensive to develop.
It has many errors.
It is not secure.

QuestionText.Text: Which of these is one of the negatives of open-source software?

AnswerSentence.Text: A central component.
A fastening device.
A big step.
A leading cause.

QuestionText.Text: In the last sentence, what does the word "staple" mean?

Material.Text: The term "open-source software" refers to software code that is available for programmers to view, use, and develop as they want. One of the major benefits of open-source software is that developers don't have to create from scratch, and they can work collaboratively with other programmers without worrying about intellectual property. Open-source projects are often (but not always) free, and they are usually more secure than their closed-source counterparts. On the down side, however, because it is open, it is possible for someone to use your code to create a competing product. Also, because these products are often made by and for developers, the user interface is not always easy to use. For many, though, the pros outweigh the cons, and open-source software remains a <u>staple</u> of the programming community.

AnswerSentence.Text: It uses powerful computing tools now.

It has tripled in size.

QuestionText.Text: According to the text, how has the stock market changed in recent years?

AnswerSentence.Text: It involves high volumes of small-value trades.
It uses computers to predict outcomes.
It trades large sums in each transaction.

QuestionText.Text: Which of these statements is true about HFT?

AnswerSentence.Text: Not all traders have equal access to the same speed of trading.
Not all traders want to use complicated HFT algorithms.
Not all traders are able to work on the market floor.
Not all traders can invest the same amounts in the stock market.

QuestionText.Text: Why might the practice of using HFT be unfair?

Material.Text: The modern stock market is changing. Whereas trading on the market once meant a mass of people yelling and waving their arms on the market floor, today's stock market employs the speed and sophistication of computer programs and complicated mathematical algorithms to trade. Since the practice of high-frequency trading (HFT) came into play near the turn of the millennium, it has been changing the face of the stock market. In HFT, computers move in and out of transactions in fractions of a second in an effort to gain just fractions of a cent on every trade. Each individual trade is inconsequential in its volume, but because these trades are made so quickly, the cumulative gain of HFT can be enormous. As this practice develops, governments are working to create policies that ensure that stock-market trading remains fair.

AnswerSentence.Text: A large design made on the ground.
Forms and images carved into stone.
A written symbol that is assigned meaning.
A three-dimensional form made by shaping.

QuestionText.Text: What is a geoglyph?

AnswerSentence.Text: They are striking in their use of a variety of bright colors.
They represent a wide variety of different images.
The purpose that they served to the Nazcas is unknown.
Some of them are remarkable in their size.

QuestionText.Text: Which of these statements is NOT true about the Nazca lines?

AnswerSentence.Text: They have been protected by the mild climate.
They are located in a desert valley.
They are on shady and protected hillsides.
They have been classified as a World Heritage Site.

QuestionText.Text: Why have the Nazca lines maintained their form over the centuries?

Material.Text: On the Nazca Plateau in southern Peru lie hundreds of ancient geoglyphs depicting animals, people, and designs. The Nazca culture created them approximately 1,500 years ago by removing the darker, reddish pebbles from the surface to expose the lighter-colored soil underneath. Since the plateau where they are located receives little wind or rain, these "Nazca Lines" have remained largely unchanged for centuries. What is impressive about some of these figures is their size: some of them are more than 200 meters (660 feet) wide. Their purpose, however, remains a mystery. Some have hypothesized that they served astronomical purposes, marking constellations and the solstices, while others think they may have served religious purposes. Unfortunately, climate change in the region could put these fragile, ancient artworks at risk.
